articles.headline: Gina Haspel Likely to Be Confirmed as C.I.A. Chief After Repudiating Torture
articles.snippet: After refusing at her confirmation hearing to condemn the C.I.A.’s use of torture after 9/11, she wrote in a letter that the agency should not have undertaken that program.
articles.abstract: After refusing at her confirmation hearing to condemn the C.I.A.’s use of torture after 9/11, she wrote in a letter that the agency should not have undertaken that program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gina Haspel, President Trump’s nominee to lead the C.I.A., appeared on Tuesday to have secured the votes to be confirmed after she declared that the agency should not have undertaken its interrogation program in which Qaeda detainees were tortured after the Sept. 11 attacks. She had refused to condemn the program at her confirmation hearing last week.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Insists Making Poor People Work Lifts Them Up. Where’s the Proof?
articles.snippet: President Trump and congressional Republicans are reviving an enduring party view that tying work requirements to antipoverty programs benefits those in need. There’s little evidence that’s so.
articles.abstract: President Trump and congressional Republicans are reviving an enduring party view that tying work requirements to antipoverty programs benefits those in need. There’s little evidence that’s so.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s something almost eerie about the unwavering nature of the Republican system of belief.

articles.headline: North Korea Threatens to Call Off Summit Meeting With Trump
articles.snippet: The news from North Korea injected sudden tension and uncertainty into what had been months of warming relations on the Korean Peninsula.
articles.abstract: The news from North Korea injected sudden tension and uncertainty into what had been months of warming relations on the Korean Peninsula.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea threw President Trump’s planned summit meeting with its leader, Kim Jong-un, into doubt on Wednesday, threatening to call off the landmark encounter if the United States insisted on “unilateral nuclear abandonment.”
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Suspect Identified in C.I.A. Leak Was Charged, but Not for the Breach
articles.snippet: After the release of C.I.A. hacking tools last year, The Times has learned the suspect’s identity. He’s been charged, but in a separate child pornography case.
articles.abstract: After the release of C.I.A. hacking tools last year, The Times has learned the suspect’s identity. He’s been charged, but in a separate child pornography case.
articles.lead_paragraph: In weekly online posts last year, WikiLeaks released a stolen archive of secret documents about the Central Intelligence Agency’s hacking operations, including software exploits designed to take over iPhones and turn smart television sets into surveillance devices.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Ruling on Airbus Subsidies Could Escalate Trade Tensions With Europe
articles.snippet: The World Trade Organization found that Europe had improperly subsidized Airbus to the detriment of Boeing. The Trump administration said it could retaliate against imports of European products.
articles.abstract: The World Trade Organization found that Europe had improperly subsidized Airbus to the detriment of Boeing. The Trump administration said it could retaliate against imports of European products.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The World Trade Organization opened the door for the Trump administration to impose billions of dollars in retaliatory sanctions on European imports with a landmark ruling Tuesday that Europe had illegally subsidized the aircraft giant Airbus to the detriment of its American competitor Boeing.

articles.headline: Fox Settles Discrimination Lawsuits for Roughly $10 Million
articles.snippet: The racial and gender discrimination lawsuits, involving 18 current and former employees, came after a reckoning that began in 2016.
articles.abstract: The racial and gender discrimination lawsuits, involving 18 current and former employees, came after a reckoning that began in 2016.
articles.lead_paragraph: Attempting to put to rest a drama that has plagued Fox News since the summer of 2016, the network’s parent company has reached a roughly $10 million settlement to resolve a group of racial and gender discrimination lawsuits involving 18 current and former employees, according to a document viewed by The New York Times and three people briefed on the deal.

articles.headline: Businesses Race to Washington to Sway Trump on China Tariffs
articles.snippet: Some of those testifying about the proposal commended the tariffs, and others criticized them. But all agreed on the potential for the plan to irrevocably alter the course of their businesses.
articles.abstract: Some of those testifying about the proposal commended the tariffs, and others criticized them. But all agreed on the potential for the plan to irrevocably alter the course of their businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mary Buchzeiger describes herself as a proud Republican who was drawn to President Trump’s business-friendly philosophy. But the president’s plan to impose sweeping tariffs on $50 billion of products from China now threatens to cripple an automotive supply business in Michigan that her father began and that she has spent years building.

articles.headline: Israelis Reflect on Gaza: ‘I Hope at Least That Each Bullet Was Justified’
articles.snippet: A day after their soldiers killed 60 mostly unarmed Palestinians in Gaza, Israelis were defiant, defensive or blasé.
articles.abstract: A day after their soldiers killed 60 mostly unarmed Palestinians in Gaza, Israelis were defiant, defensive or blasé.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAHAL OZ, Israel — Daniel Rahamim, 63, had four Palestinians from nearby Gaza at his wedding in 1983. He remembers sunbathing on Gaza’s beaches, and drinking tea at a friend’s antique shop there.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner and David M. Halbfinger

articles.headline: Chris Paul: Point Guard, Activist, Union Boss
articles.snippet: CP3 plays many roles in the N.B.A. Besides being the starting point guard for the Rockets, he is an outspoken voice on social issues, and leads the player union.
articles.abstract: CP3 plays many roles in the N.B.A. Besides being the starting point guard for the Rockets, he is an outspoken voice on social issues, and leads the player union.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since Chris Paul joined the National Basketball Association in 2005, drafted fourth out of Wake Forest, he has been near the center of the action.

articles.headline: New Privacy Rules Could Make This Woman One of Tech’s Most Important Regulators
articles.snippet: With Europe’s sweeping new data privacy law, Ireland is in the middle of a standoff between regulators and tech companies.
articles.abstract: With Europe’s sweeping new data privacy law, Ireland is in the middle of a standoff between regulators and tech companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — If Mark Zuckerberg doesn’t know who Helen Dixon is, he will soon.
